BE11:12am

Following yesterday’s parliamentary voting the UK is set for a winter election on 12th December. With the vote
split between more parties than in the past, there is more uncertainty in trying to predict the result. The
unusual timing of this election also introduces an added element of uncertainty due to potentially low turnout.
As we discuss below, however, we do not think its timing should automatically be expected to meaningfully
skew the result.
As things stand our weekly polling analysis indicates a near 10%-pt lead for the Conservatives which could
translate into something like a 30-40 seat majority. In addition to this current snapshot, the idea of a
December election also met some resistance from opposition parties due to concerns about the impact of
winter weather conditions on turnout and the ability of students returning home from university to vote (i.e.
depending on the location they are registered).
On the issue of weather, the first chart below shows historical turnout at previous U.K. general elections since
1918. There have been several winter elections, but there does not appear to have been a clear tendency for
these to produce lower than normal turnout. Indeed, the highest turnout seen during the prior century was
recorded in the winter election of 1950, when the average temperature for the month was 4oC.

tangledodyssey Odds on a White Election?
JaPe @irish hf - thanks
11:12 am
BE11:13am

Blank canvas Chomsky: yes, ends about second week in November unless Uncle Lionel buys a new hamster to keep things running
BE11:13am

The second chart shows there is no real correlation between average temperatures and voter turnout. The
greater concern would instead appear to be whether there could be heavy snowfall or other adverse
conditions on the day which prevent people from voting. The conventional wisdom is that this is more likely to
deter Labour voters, and by region any impact might be most prominent in Scotland and the rural areas of the
UK. According to the met office, however, December is the least snowy month of winter with 3.9 days of
snowfall on average.
On the second issue of student votes, YouGov this week pointed out that 70% of students in 2017 voted in
their home constituencies. That still leaves 30% that are not. But this point does also detract from a broader
and potentially more significant issue. Whilst younger voters are the least likely to use their vote, there has
been a sharp rise in the proportion of 18-24yrs voting in recent years – as shown in the third chart below.
Engagement of social media platforms during the campaign is likely to be key. And if the turnout trend among
younger voters continues this could hand an advantage to Labour and the Liberal Democrats.
One would hope that such trends in turnout are already captured in the opinion polls. But the biggest problem
those companies have faced during the past two elections is knowing how to weight survey responses to
ensure accurate representation of the voting population. That issue hasn’t got any easier this time with more
parties present and rapidly changing trends in turnout.

Throughout the Brexit process to date, we had argued that a pre-Brexit general
nelection was neither major party’s preferred route to resolution. Now that a December election has been announced (subject to no further amendments in the House of Lords), we push back the resolution implicit in our baseline path from November to January, but we maintain the base case of a Brexit deal. Our central scenario is now one in which Boris Johnson returns as Prime Minister with a parliamentary majority sufficient to ratify the latest version of the Withdrawal Agreement and Political Declaration, as negotiated with the EU in mid-October.

As for the distribution of risks, we continue to attach a 5% probability to a “no
ndeal” Brexit. Given Boris Johnson’s renewed commitment to his own Brexit deal, and Jeremy Corbyn’s new commitment to a second referendum, we see little scope for the Brexit Party to command enough influence in the next Parliament to force “no deal” back onto the agenda. In the event the Conservative Party is beaten, the prospect that the next Parliament coalesces around a confirmatory referendum leads us to raise our “no Brexit” probability from 25% to 30%. With both plausible prime ministerial candidates in pursuit of a negotiated Withdrawal Agreement, at least in the first instance, we still see a Brexit deal as the most likely outcome of the enduring impasse, but we nudge down our deal probability from 70% to 65%.

BE11:18am

Now that a firm election dater has been inked into the diary, we finally have a little more substance on which to strike calls on the house building sector. There have been some wild gyrations in the sector in the last two months driven primarily by a hope or belief that a no deal Brexit was off the table. Now, however, we have replaced what appeared to be confidence with fresh doubt and uncertainty and, as we wrote a few days ago, we believe that uncertainty is a killer for the housing market. As there is a great deal of uncertainty about the outcome on December 12th and the two parties that might occupy No. 10 will have polar opposite agendas, we believe that many buyers will now adopt a wait-and-see position.

The house builders had been buoyed by 1) the hope that a no deal Brexit had been avoided; 2) that Brexit will deliver a substantial economic dividend; 3) that a Budget on 6th November would slash Stamp Duty and set the housing market alight. All of these seemed increasingly certain and we have seen most stocks swing from 12 months lows to 12 month or even all time highs. Now we face a pause at least in the market that is likely to straddle the year end and flow into early 2020. If the Tories are returned, an emergency Budget will come in the early days of January we feel that buyers and sellers will want to wait to see what extra incentives and stimuli are introduced. If Labour wins, buyers are likely also to wait to see what attacks there might be on personal wealth and other confidence sappers. Both potential outcomes point to hiatus.

We have discussed all of the potential issues before but we see a loss of sales momentum in the key push for December year-end sales, a dent in forward order books and the likely need to offer more incentives to buyers through the end of 2019 and into the new year. Previously we have only really been concerned about the impact of wider market pricing on margins due to the loss of house price momentum but now we also need to be concerned about weaker sales volumes and an additional bout of pricing pressure via incentive and higher selling costs that are unique to new homes. Private buyers and sellers can afford to sit the uncertain times out but house builders have targets and expectations to meet.

Are we there yet Comments section change is OK - but nothing like the real-time back and for you get here
11:18 am
BE11:18am

he house building sector is one prone is quick and severe knee-jerk reactions and we have seen how far and how fast share prices have moved on even the merest whiff of pivotal change. While the surge that we have seen in the sector has receded a little, most house builder’s share prices are well above their mid-summer lows and substantially above the recent trough we saw just before Christmas 2018. We believe there is now the risk of another and negative knee-jerk reaction in the sector. While we do not see that we will return to the December 2018 lows (that was driven by Project Fear on a No deal exit) there is scope for a material wind back. In the table below we show how far stocks have moved from the late 2018 and summer 2019 lows: we do not expect that prices will move to anywhere near the 12 month lows but towards the summer lows could be a decent guide.

Irish HF guy source: De la rue 2019 annual report, $7tn cash worldwide.

The sector typically moves en masse so if we are to see a notch down it is likely to be universal and if looking at stock picks, almost anything in the sector will suffice. We have been suggesting that the current sector valuations have been over-pricing optimism and under-pricing risk for some time and we stand by that view. The sector already faced the risk of earnings shocks and surprises from the loss of forward momentum in house prices, in our view, but the risks have now been heightened.

This is a slightly better than expected Q3 sales performance from Next
(Q3 brand sales +2.0%, a touch ahead of guidance and consensus for
c.+1.6%), but full year guidance is unchanged. Performance was supported
by a strong October (+5.0%) which Next believes benefitted from pent-up
demand through September. As a result management is not extrapolating
this out into Q4 and hence FY 20 guidance is unchanged on all lines (note
though that even unchanged guidance implies brand sales growth of
c.+3.6% in the final quarter anyway).

BE11:31am

On balance, given the recent strength in the stock [Next now trading on a PE of c.15x], we expect the shares to move slightly lower today. However, with regards to read across to the rest of the sector, whilst other retailers had called out an improvement in October, the c.+5% rate achieved by Next is better than we had anticipated, and we therefore expect this to be read across positively, particularly to ABF

Q: How did the results compare vs expectations?
A: Smurfit Kappa Group (SKG) reported Q3 2019 sales of €2,228m (UBSe 2,459m) while EBITDA came in at €410m (UBSe 412m), up by 1% y-o-y and representing a margin of 18.4% (UBSe: 16.7%). There is no consensus available for the quarter and these are the only numbers the company published in its trading update.
Q: What were the most noteworthy areas in the results?
A: According to the company, corrugated volumes growth was 4% for the first nine months of the year and approximately 2% on an organic basis (UBSe: 2%) while corrugated pricing was said to have been in line with the company's expectations. In the Americas, organic volumes growth was approximately 2% (UBSe: 2%) with continued EBITDA and EBITDA margin improvement y-o-y.

I remember being in 1 hostel and the guy could not book me at the desk, I had to go on hostelworld to book. Those days are gradually disappearing. I think they still have a 50% 60% share of reservations systems. Personally I think an "experiences" entity would be the best partner for Hostelworld

Q: Has the company's outlook/guidance changed?
A: The earlier guidance (expect to deliver another year of progress) was not mentioned in this trading update, but according to management the year-to-date progression (EBITDA up 11%) speaks for itself. We note that for FY 2019e consensus (Reuters Eikon) expects EBITDA adjusted of €1,623m; this is up 5% y-o-y or €78m but includes IFRS 16 (leasing) effects of c€80m, which makes for an assumption of flat underlying EBITDA. A key focus point on the conference call will be on box pricing (we expect flattish box prices y-o-y in 2019 and -3% in 2020, which translates into -6% from the peak late-2018); Mondi (Buy) recently said in its trading update that the willingness among producers to pass on more of the containerboard decline to box pricing has increased recently. Previously DS Smith (Neutral) indicated 1-3% lower box pricing into Q3 19. However, we do not expect SKG to give implicit guidance on pricing.

11:37 am
BE11:37am

Valuation: Buy, PT €33; How would we expect investors to react?
A: Slightly positively. Current H2 19 consensus EBITDA at €776m points to a 5% y-o-y decline (vs. H1 19 being up 17% y-o-y and Q3 19 up 1%), and we would therefore expect to see some positive revisions (with spill-over into 2020). The share is up by 8% in the last month and by 27% year-to-date but we would still expect to see an initial slight positive reaction today. In terms of read-across, solid Q3 19 earnings and volumes could boost sentiment for key peers

By geography, we believe dealer density would limit the risk of divestment or antitrust opposition despite market shares greater than 40% in Italy and

35% in France. LatAm would complement given FCA and PSA respective strengths in Brazil and Argentina. No overlap in NA and opportunity for scale in China. By segment light duty vans would come under scrutiny with combined share at c.35%. On LCVs, we note that PSA is set to launch a one-ton medium duty pickup on a platform co-developed with Changan, which should be of interest to FCA.

BE11:41am

Synergies in a €3-5bn range could be worth €13-18bn - In previous research we had estimated the cost of restructuring EMEA exposure at €2-3bn including capacity reduction with equivalent savings through optimized development of platform and electrified powertrain. In the aborted merger offer with Renault, FCA had estimated synergies of €5bn (80% effective year 5 and 100% year 6) with implementation costs of €3-4bn. Given relative exposure we find such numbers still relevant in a potential PSA-FCA combination given EU size and exposure. Assuming retained savings in a €3-5bn range by year 5-6, taxed at 25%, capitalized on a mid cycle PE multiple of 7-8x yields incremental value in a range of €13-18bn discounted at 10%.

BE11:43am

We continue to believe a FCA-RNO tie-up makes more sense than a FCA-PSA merger, given that Renault is farther along on EVs than PSA, and as such, could better solve FCA’s CO2 dilemma. That said, given last week’s profit warning, struggles at Nissan, and management shake-up, we think RNO’s bargaining power in consummating a deal with FCA especially with PSA reportedly in the picture, is likely at its worst position thus far. We believe that the initial RNO-FCA deal collapsed due to disagreements over how to value RNO’s Nissan stake. In a strange way, we wonder if PSA’s involvement brings RNO back to the table with terms more amenable to FCA. Such an event would be positive for RNO shares, but perhaps less so at less favourable terms for RNO. Either way, both RNO and PSA have French government ownership interest and would thus have to clear that obstacle. Furthermore, if history is any indication, we likely have not seen the end of this saga. We continue to believe should RNO reach a deal ultimately with Nissan and/or FCA, it could be positive for shares. Today’s news, however, will likely push RNO shares lower, given that many investors are in the name for a deal, and PSA’s involvement does put that in question.

BE11:44am

And some maths from Commerzbank

11:44 am
BE11:44am

The combined entity (pre-synergies) would be a 6.8% EBIT margin business, deriving almost half its unit sales from Western Europe, and almost a third from the US. Combined market cap (pre-merger speculation) is €41bn of which €22.5bn is PSA and €18.5bn is FCA. Both companies have net cash on the balance sheet, and combined net cash/EBITDA would be 0.53x. Of note are FCA's significant pension liabilities (€8.5bn) and PSA's significant minority interest (€2.5bn).

BE11:45am

Based on our perception of 1) the two companies' respective motives and 2) the apparent industrial logic, we place the probability of a successful merger above 50%. We believe a PSA combination would be a substantially less politically fraught process than the prior Renault proposal: France should be less able to/inclined to due to its lower influence at PSA (13.7% stake) vs. Renault (15% and double voting rights). Plus there is no third party (Nissan/Mitsubishi) to appease. If realized, this merger will be positive for European capacity utilization, pricing, and OEM sector sentiment. It would also be positive for the two involved parties.

PSA is making good progress in reducing its fleet CO2 over 2019, which puts it in a good position to achieve compliance [net of the 5% relief rule] in 2020 thanks to stop sales of older cars and help from lower emitting new launches. Furthermore, while a combined PSA/FCA would still lag many peers in certain emissions tech aspects [e.g. the lack of a proper dedicated battery electric vehicle platform] the improved geographic diversity would enable the group to withstand the european headwind better and de-risk the overall investment case. We raise our PSA price target to €28 on a target EV/Adjusted EBIT multiple of 3.1x and upgrade to Buy [from Reduce].

With MedTech stock valuations closely linked to the directionality of the organic sales growth, we expect the stock to be up significantly today, driven by multiple expansion. While the company has maintained its FY19E guidance, easy comparisons in Q4 FY19E would suggest that the organic sales growth can exit the year comfortably at +5%, which should provide a useful catalyst over the next 3-months. For Q3 the company highlights that Advanced Wound Care may have been positively impacted by distributor inventory movements, which may partly reverse in Q4. With a new CEO, coming from Genus Plc, a key focus for the equity story will be his expected strategy update in Q1 FY20, which should more clearly set-out his medium-term expectations, with respect to the required investment in R&D and sales force, which could temporarily provide a headwind to margins and profitability. We have an Equal-weight recommendation.
